overview.short: Kosakonia cowanii is a Gram-negative, facultatively anaerobic rod in the Enterobacterales, primarily environmental/plant-associated but occasionally reported from clinical specimens.
overview.clinical_context: Uncommon opportunist; when recovered clinically, interpret in context of specimen source and contamination risk.

species_markers.value: High when VP positive + oxidase negative + motile Enterobacterales profile
species_markers.notes: Biochemical overlap is common; species-level certainty often requires MALDI-TOF or sequencing.
Indole variability means this field should not be used alone for species calling.
Citrate can vary; interpret alongside VP/MR pattern and broader sugar profile.

common_confusions.reason: Very similar Enterobacterales biochemical patterns (VP positive, oxidase negative, motile).
Enterobacterales overlap; confirm via MALDI-TOF/ID panels.

when_to_question_identification: Non-motile isolate argues against K. cowanii.
Strong MR-positive / VP-negative pattern suggests Escherichia-like organisms rather than Kosakonia.
If isolate is from a sterile site, confirm with MALDI-TOF or sequencing due to rarity and contamination risk.

recommended_next_tests.reason: Provides a structured Enterobacterales biochemical pattern to support genus-level placement.
Often required for confident separation from Enterobacter and related genera.
Best for definitive species confirmation in reclassified/closely related Enterobacterales.
